stories.text:
It looks like a deceptive practice. I made a typo when trying to visit DigitalOcean, and landed on Vultr's website instead.

http://digitaloean.com/

I realize it is perfectly acceptable in an open marketplace to leverage all legal methods to maximize traffic to your store. But I would've really appreciated it if there was an interstitial page, visible for at least for a few seconds, that told the visitor that they have mistyped the domain name, and that they are now being redirected to Vultr's site.

I'm an existing customer of Vultr, and this experience didn't really lift up their image in my mind. Doing the above suggested, or something similar, would've made me like them more.

Edit: Addendum: Given that their color schemes are almost identical, and that my password manager auto-filled credentials, I even clicked on relevant buttons to login and almost launched a VM there.
stories.title: Tell HN: Vultr is Typosquatting on misspelling of DigitalOcean.com

stories.text:
Hey, I'm looking for suggestions on a book to help relearn some math.

I went through engineering school and had to take many advanced math classes, but it's been enough years that I've forgotten much of what I had learned. I'm sure it is not all forgotten, it just needs to be reawoken.

I was considering picking up some textbooks, but then I remembered I didn't find them all that helpful back then so that is unlikely to have changed.

Maybe what I'm hoping for doesn't exist, but it would be great to find a book that does a high level overview of lots of different types of math and relates those to some real world scenarios. I've found this grokking algorithms book which has been helpful but I haven't found something analogous for mathematics.

If you know of any good books I would appreciate you sharing it.
stories.title: Ask HN: Book Suggestions for Relearning Math
